articles.headline: In First Lady’s Roots, a Complex Path From Slavery
articles.snippet: A newly discovered story has fleshed out Michelle Obama’s family tree.
articles.abstract: A newly discovered story has fleshed out Michelle Obama’s family tree.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In 1850, the elderly master of a South Carolina estate took pen in hand and painstakingly divided up his possessions. Among the spinning wheels, scythes, tablecloths and cattle that he bequeathed to his far-flung heirs was a 6-year-old slave girl valued soon afterward at $475.
articles.byline: By Rachel L. Swarns and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: As a Phone, It Makes a Good GPS
articles.snippet: Garmin’s combination smartphone and GPS unit has superior features for providing directions. But as a phone, it faces strong competition.
articles.abstract: Garmin’s combination smartphone and GPS unit has superior features for providing directions. But as a phone, it faces strong competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the beginning, certain high-tech pairings have made eminent sense: Clock+radio. Camera+cellphone. Fridge+freezer.

articles.headline: U.S. Begins Antitrust Inquiry of I.B.M.
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is investigating whether I.B.M. abused its monopoly position in a vital computing market.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is investigating whether I.B.M. abused its monopoly position in a vital computing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has started a preliminary investigation into whether I.B.M. has abused its monopoly position in the market for mainframe computers, which remain vital to many of the world’s largest businesses. This month, antitrust regulators at the Justice Department began seeking information about I.B.M.’s business practices from companies that compete with I.B.M. in the market for large computer hardware and software, people who had been contacted in the inquiry said.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: In Merrill’s Failed Plan, Lessons for Pay Czar
articles.snippet: Merrill’s attempt to align pay with performance did not keep executives from risking the bank’s stability.
articles.abstract: Merrill’s attempt to align pay with performance did not keep executives from risking the bank’s stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like something Washington’s pay czar might propose to rein in runaway bonuses on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Afghan War Debate Now Leans to Focus on Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: President Obama’s national security team is arguing that the Afghan Taliban don’t pose a direct threat to the U.S.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s national security team is arguing that the Afghan Taliban don’t pose a direct threat to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s national security team is moving to reframe its war strategy by emphasizing the campaign against Al Qaeda in Pakistan while arguing that the Taliban in Afghanistan do not pose a direct threat to the United States, officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Leader Ousted, Honduras Hires U.S. Lobbyists
articles.snippet: The campaign has forced the administration to send mixed signals about the de facto government.
articles.abstract: The campaign has forced the administration to send mixed signals about the de facto government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  First, depose a president. Second, hire a lobbyist.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Thousands of Homeowners Cite Drywall for Ills
articles.snippet: Tainted drywall installed in post-hurricane building booms has caused health problems, homeowners say.
articles.abstract: Tainted drywall installed in post-hurricane building booms has caused health problems, homeowners say.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bill Morgan, a retired policeman, moved into his newly built dream home in Williamsburg, Va., three years ago, his hopes were quickly dashed.

articles.headline: Inside CBS, Disbelief at an Arrest
articles.snippet: Inside CBS News, Robert Joel Halderman was a widely liked and well-regarded producer, known for chasing action and taking chances.
articles.abstract: Inside CBS News, Robert Joel Halderman was a widely liked and well-regarded producer, known for chasing action and taking chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside CBS News, Robert Joel Halderman was a widely liked and well-regarded producer, known for chasing action and taking chances.

articles.headline: Travel Sector Takes Steps to Resist Flu
articles.snippet: Hotels, airports and airlines are seeking a balance between taking preventive steps and acting so aggressively that they panic travelers.
articles.abstract: Hotels, airports and airlines are seeking a balance between taking preventive steps and acting so aggressively that they panic travelers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The travel industry was hard hit after the first reports of swine flu emerged from Mexico in the spring. Trips were canceled, destination weddings were moved elsewhere and flights were grounded as traveler demand plummeted.

articles.headline: Retailers’ Sales for September Only Reach 2005 Levels
articles.snippet: Several stores reported better-than-expected results, but the comparison is to a year ago when business collapsed because of the financial meltdown.
articles.abstract: Several stores reported better-than-expected results, but the comparison is to a year ago when business collapsed because of the financial meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a small step toward economic recovery, but a giant step toward lifting the spirits of the nation’s retailers.
